This is a brief but thought provoking discussion between the developer (and his interpretation of Albert Camus) and the player. It is philosophical without being too alientating--no jargon to deal with. I enjoyed the circular "pointless" conversations with the various diggers before arriving at the Pyramid--the sense of humor reminded me a little of that "Who's on First?" joke and the Gravedigger in Hamlet. The art is very simple but effective for its subject.

I quite enjoyed this short adventure game that questions the existance of choice in our lives, while still allowing for individuality. In seeking the full achievements for this game, I made it more Sisyphean than needed by avoiding walkthroughs until I was frustrated [spoiler]and I was digging in the "right" place 12 times and seeing the ending that many times as well without an acheivement pop[/spoiler]. This led to some of the charm of the experience wearing off, so avoid that if you can!

37156472.review:
Kısa bir kurgu ile metaforlar üzerinden, samimi ve yalın diyaloglarla hayat tecrübesi aktarmayı amaçlayan, point&click türünde bir oyun. Varoluşun kendisini ve yaşam dediğimiz şeyi irdelemeyi hedefliyor. 

Hangi formda olduğunuzu, bulunduğunuz yere ne zaman geldiğinizi, bulunduğunuz konumun neresi olduğunu bilmediğiniz siyah-beyaz bir yerde uyanıyor ve cevap bulmaya çalışıyorsunuz, buradan sonrasında oyun sizi sürüklüyor.

[h1]Bundan sonrası [b]SPOILER[/b] içerir, ona göre okuyunuz:[/h1]

Önünüzü kesen sarkıtı taşla kırıyor, mağaranın sonundaki deliği o kırdığınız sarkıt ile yarıyor ve dışarıya, bir çöle çıkıyorsunuz. Çöl çok sıcak ve yaşama dair pek bir şey yok, var olan ağaçlar ve otlar kurumuş. Çölde size benzeyen varlıklarla karşılaşıyorsunuz ama sadece kumları kazarak çukur oluşturuyor ve geri dolduruyorlar, bunu neden yaptıklarını ise düşünmüyorlar. İçlerinden bir tanesi sorularınıza cevap alabilmeniz için sizi bir bilgeye yönlendiriyor. Bilgeye nerede olduğunuzu, ne zaman geldiğinizi, buradan nasıl kurtulacağınızı, burada neden hiç gelişkin bir medeniyet olmadığını, neden birilerinin işe yarar bir şeyler yapmak için çalışmadığını vs. soruyorsunuz. Bilge bunların çoğunu "aşmış" bir karakter, bu var oluşa herkesten önce gelmiş ve her yolu denemiş. Size "ne olacak, bilsen ne elde edeceksin, var olmak nedir ki zaten, ben üretmeyi denedim inan hiçbir işe yaramıyor" gibisinden cevaplar veriyor. Ondan sonra size 3 tane yol sunuyor, bu yolların herhangi birisini tercih etmek oyunun bitmesi anlamına geliyor:

- Var olduğunu hissedebilmek ve bir amacı gerçekleştirebilmek için kum çukuru kazıp sonra bu çukuru dolduranlardan olmak. (Bilge bu yolu seçmenizi öneriyor, kazmak için kullanacağınız küreği nereden bulacağınızı da o öğretiyor)
- Bir yerde toplanıp hareketsizce durarak var olmaya dair her şeyi unutan topluluktan olmak. 
- İçinde bulunduğunuz çölde bir şeyler aramaya çıkarak kaybolmak.

4. yolu ise siz buluyorsunuz. Mağaranıza geri dönüyor, akan suyun yumuşattığı taşı kazarak yerin dibine doğru ilerliyorsunuz. Farklı bir evrene ulaşmayı başarıyorsunuz, burada renkler ve yaşayan kocaman bir ağaç var. Burada ise size sunulanların ötesinde "kendi yolunuzu" üretmiş oluyorsunuz. 

Açıklaması,

Oyunda imgeleştirilen varlık tiplerini günümüz dünyasında bulmaya çalışırsak bence şu 4 tipe vurgu yapılıyor: 

1- bir işe girip çalışarak ve kazandığı parayı harcayarak, toplumda ne yapılıyorsa ona uyarak hayatını nihayete erdirmeye çalışan tüketim bireyleri. (kum kazanlar)
2- kendini uyuşturmayı ve hissizleşmeyi seçen bireyler, bunlar "hazcı" bireyler de olabilir, toplumun normlarına uymayan ama üretici de olamamış kesim. (topluluk halinde durup hiçbir şey yapmayanlar)
3- intihar edenler, bu var oluşu terk edenler. (görünürde hiç hayat olmamasına rağmen çölü gezmeye çıkanlar)
4- bir yol bulmaya çalışan, önüne sunulan nesnel koşulları değiştirmek için mücadele etmeyi seçen bireyler. (mağarada suyun yumuşattığı taşı kazarak diğer var oluşa geçmeyi başaranlar)

Bir var oluşa, nasıl olduğunuzu bilmeden dahil oluyor, çıkış ararken umutsuzluğa kapılıp o var oluşun içinde kendinize bir amaç edinmeye çalışıyorsunuz. Burada size akıl verenlerin ne kadar uzun süredir o var oluşun içinde bulunduğu gerçeği önemini yitiriyor çünkü o varlık ne kadar bilge olursa olsun, içine düştüğü nesnelliği değiştirmenin ya da farklı koşulların şekillendirdiği bir var oluşa geçmenin yollarını aramamış. İçinde bulunduğu koşulları rasyonalize etmeye çalışmış sadece. Eğer gerçekten bir şeyleri değiştirmek istiyorsanız, diğer insanların size gösterdiği yoldan faydalanabilirsiniz ama onlar size tüm yolu göstermezler mesela, gerçek bir çözüm için diğerlerinin bilemeyeceği kendinize ait olan tecrübeleri düşünmeniz lazım. Falan filan...

Velhasıl, ilginç bir oyun. Üzerine epey konuşulur ama burası onun yeri değil ve ben o kadar fazla şey bilmiyorum hayatla ilgili :) dizaynı ve kurgusu biraz daha geliştirilerek birkaç dolardan satılabilir aslında, ücretsiz koyarak kendilerine haksızlık etmişler.

36642184.review:
Sisyphus Reborn is a short, atmospheric, indie adventure game. It is available free, or if, like me, you enjoy it, you can buy the 'Collector's Edition', a DLC which gives you the soundtrack, art book and deleted scenes along with the ability to keep the game in your library for £0.79!

It has a minimal, black and white, hand-drawn art style, which suits the concept well and proved to be quite striking. The UI, in general, was quite basic, but more than sufficient. The in-game text was also less visually appealing and was difficult to read at times, especially being white with a black outline on a white background! The soundtrack is quite pretty, sticking to the minimalist feel, but with distinct tracks for different areas.

 I imagine there were many time and/or budget constraints, among others, and the developers have worked well with these limitations, even using them to an advantage, creating a game that is consistent in both concept and tone.

As the protagonist, you find yourself in an unknown place which you traverse in an attempt to find reason and purpose and eventually escape. You'll need to complete the small (and simple) puzzles that are dotted between vaguely philosophical musings questioning fate, autonomy, meaning and existence in general. 

I completed Sisyphus Reborn, with all achievements in just under 1 hour, including time spent making a cup of coffee. Overall, I enjoyed the game and would recommend it to anyone wanting a short, contemplative experience.



If you enjoyed this and would like to see my game reviews (and a bunch of other ramblings) in their natural habitat please visit my [url=www.rachaelbreartonwrites.com]blog[/url]

36311842.review:
[h1]Disclaimer: Contains one or nine spoilers[/h1]

I love absolutely everything about this game except its protagonist, but that fault is a proper Achilles' heel, and so I cannot positively recomment the game because a lot of its experience, thematic, narrative and gameplay hinges on the protagonist. For a fair review, I'll start with the few things that charmed me as both a philosophy and a horror nerd: 

[list]
[*] The Score - Outstanding job Edwin Montgomery. If it wasn't the texture of your sound when the protagonist fumbled to pick up a rock, or the crunch that followed a broken tree branch, it was the beautifully haunting melody that crept behind me the whole game. 

[*] The Art Style - Really creative and hand drawn animations. I enjoyed the sketch style it had to them, and it gave the title a good degree of authenticity and originality to go along with it.

[*] The Atmosphere - Actually a combination of both the score, and the art style: [b]Sisyphus Reborn[/b] is big on atmosphere. The setting, among everything else, really encapsulates the absurd, lonely and hopeless theme of it all.

[*] Game mechanics - simple, easy and straightforward point-and-click mechanics. Left-click to examine, Right-click to interact/move.

[*] The fact that it's a reference to Albert Camus' The Myth of Sisyphus, with [spoiler]Sisyphus being the "One that was there before the others[/spoiler]
[/list]

Regardless, I have to say I found the writing to choppy, pretentious and contradictory to its own purpose. It starts of well -- with the protagonist being quite literally a deductive soul, analyzing their environment, and logically applying one observation to another to progress through the level. However, as soon as they get out of [b]The Cave[/b], that's where it noticeably begins to drop in quality. The protagonist escapes the cave, and with them comes an unsatiated thirst for answers. You leave The Cave and enter [b]The Desert[/b], a dry, lifeless place with a few [b]Diggers[/b], going about their business. You interrupt the first [b]Digger[/b] you meet in what is most likely the hottest day of all the year, and bombard them with all these hard-hitting philosophical queries. In return, the Digger, answers in purposefully vague and unhelpfull answers that force you to dispatch them and forge onward. You approach the second Digger, or maybe the third, and you initiate a conversation by claiming: "You wouldn't happen to tell me something of actual value, as oppossed to those dimwits before us, right?" Or, you know, something to that effect. That Digger, probably annoyed at your egregious display of arrogance, answers: "Fuck off mate, I can't help you." Or, you know, something to that effect.

And now, listen, before you other philosophy nerds out there smash their keyboards typing up a reply to my last paragraph, let me save you the time and say: [b]I know[/b]. I know one of the fundamental tenets from Albert Camus' The Myth of Sisyphus, layed out in Chapter 1, is that the answer to "Does the realization of the meaninglessness and absurdity of life necessarily require suicide?" is [b]NO![/b], and instead one should [b]revolt![/b]. But that does not award you a get-out-of-being a pretentious, judgemental, and just overall jerk. These other souls made their choice, and that was [b]to dig[/b]. Why are you judging them? Why are you judging the souls that chose [b]not to dig[/b]? Why are you harassing them while their literally fulfilling their purpose of existence? Not to mention digging is hard work. 

Anyways, at some point one Digger tells you to go to [b]The Pyramid[/b] and ask it questions. So you go, ring some bells (OK so they also sound beautiful because this game has an incredible sound designer, whatever), and you meet "The One who was there before The Others". This is essentially Sisyphus -- an arrogant and deceitfull soul that is forced to watch every civilization they create crumble before it rebirths, and crumbles again and so forth. He tells you, the reason those "digging plebs" before you were of no help was because they were stupid, and instead [b]you[/b] are the smart one that we've all been waiting for. The One who was there before the Others continues to say that you must choose either to dig or not to dig, then you both go judge those who chose not to dig, or "not to be". Then you build a shovel, and through sheer rugged individualism dig all your way to China, where you fall and combine with water and "earth" to become a tree. A pretentious and judgemental tree. Smh.

35178082.review:
Even if you don't know it by name, I think just about everyone has heard, to some extent, the story of Sisyphus, the crafty king in Greek mythology sentenced by the gods to roll a boulder up a hill for eternity only for it to always roll back down again. In more "recent" years, Albert Camus wrote The Myth of Sisyphus exploring the notion of the absurdity of life and living; to actively maintain participation in an act known to be futile given its lack of ultimate consequence, but to contently "revolt" by continuing to do so whilst also wilfully rejecting concepts of hope or faith. This game touches upon many of those same themes.

In this particular allegory, our Sisyphus is a stranger who awakens without any memories in a bizarre, unfamiliar land, inhabited by people who perform actions without any justifiable reason, or even clearly defined knowledge for why they really do so. What follows is a character's journey to try and understand what's going on around him, and also find his own justifications for his own actions. In case it wasn't already abundantly clear... this is a very intellectually deep, contemplative game.

Gameplay-wise, this all takes the form of a very basic, 2D, point-and-click, side-scrolling game using simplistic art and minimal animation. On a technical level, this isn't especially impressive, but that's really not where the main crux of the substance lies, as much of your time will be spent reading lots of text and delving into some complex issues of a philosophical and existential nature.

Like most good philosophy, this doesn't offer any answers, but instead raises questions whilst offering forth suggestions or positing possibilities from its own individual perspective and beliefs or opinions. As in all such cases, the recipient's millage may vary depending on how they choose to read into it.

While I'm still not actually sure how I really feel about the game on several levels, I did at the very least really enjoy the change of pace in experiencing a game which delved into a subject matter so directly where others would normally never even dream of going anywhere near. As such, I could very easily see why this wouldn't be for everyone, but am also really glad that I took the time to explore this one and could recommend that others do so, too.

34815935.review:
[h1][b]Ser o no ser[/b][/h1]

[b]Sisyphus Reborn es un título capaz de resumir un concepto como es el absurdismo en 30 min. Y lo hace a la perfección.[/b]

[h1]En algún lugar del desierto[/h1]
La historia comienza en una cueva en la que se halla una persona que no sabe porqué ni cómo ha terminado en ese oscuro lugar. Bien es cierto que es bastante tópico el uso de este recurso, pero se le perdona por la continuación que le acontece a este hecho.

Al salir, nos encontraremos un mundo, a simple vista, ridículo en el que todo el mundo está cavando, sin llegar a dar un motivo aparente a este hecho. Todos excepto una persona.

Ese individuo será el que nos haga llenarnos de cuestiones y dudas existenciales, todo ello bajo la vertiente filosófica propuesta por Camus. No voy a desvelar muchos más detalles a partir de este punto, pero os aseguro que es de las mejores experiencias que he tenido en un videojuego.

[h1]Blanco y negro[/h1]
El apartado artístico encaja perfectamente con la propuesta que ofrece el título, con un apartado gráfico basado en dibujos en blanco y negro, sin dotar de muchos detalles a los diversos elementos que se dan en la obra. La banda sonora es simplemente maravillosa, siguiendo una línea continuista pero variando discretamente según se van dando distintas situaciones.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
Sisyphus Reborn será recordado para mí como el [i]Synecdoche New York[/i] de los videojuegos, con una premisa un tanto diferente a la obra audiovisual pero convergiendo en el mismo hilo argumental: nuestra lucha por intentar dotar de sentido a nuestra vida. Una obra que insulta a nuestra existencia de una forma diplomática y sutil, pero no por ello menos dura de asimilar.

Filosofía aplicada al mundo del videojuego.

34458072.review:
[b]“Man stands face to face with the irrational. He feels within him his longing for happiness and for reason. The absurd is born of this confrontation between the human need and the unreasonable silence of the world.” ― Albert Camus, [i]The Myth of Sisyphus and Other Essays[/i][/b]

[i]Sisyphus Reborn[/i] is a short, absurd reference to the work of author/philosopher Albert Camus - [i]The Myth of Sisyphus[/i] -  rather than being a game. Being the sole project of Myshkin Entertaintment so far, it is a journey worthy of taking note if you do enjoy philosophical displays even the slightest. I, as a long standing lover of philosophy, especially existentialism, must say that this short little adventure manages to grasp the full content of Camus' work, and even challenges his theme of hope/hopelessness.

Well, to be able to understand the proper theme of the game, one has to be familiar with the story of Sisyphus first. According to the Greek myth, Sisyphus was the cunning and deceitful King of Corinth who managed to trick Thanatos - the Death itself - and chain him so no one in the world would die for some time, causing the old and the sick to suffer. As punishment, he was doomed to roll a huge boulder up a steep hill, yet every time that he would be about to accomplish the task, the boulder would roll down and he'd have to start all over again. He is the embodiment of a meaningless labor, doomed to take place for eternity without any conclusion.

In his essay, Camus describes the existence of man a paradox in this world. The world being devoid of any meaning - scientific or religious - mankind's constant pursuit for meaning would be equally devoid of meaning, even absurd. So, with the realization of this absurdity, would suicide be the only way out? Such is the philosophical issue that Camus thoroughly discusses in his work. According to Camus' conclusion though, the realization of the absurd asks for revolt. Yet, it is not the kind of revolt one would think of. One has to acknowledge the existence of the absurdity, yet keep challenging it by contended acceptance, thus the work itself becomes our own meaning. Such acceptance of futility would be the only freedom the absurd man can hope for.

Grim, huh? It surely is, considering existentialism and absurdity are philosophies born just after the WWII. Let's take a look back at the game though. This short little adventure world portraits the vision of Camus explicitly, yet bears a completely different approach for its conclusion - a bit close to Sartre rather than Camus. The futility dominates all conditions within, yet bearing the minimum of choices, if one manages to choose even a slightly different path dominated by his own rule... - you have to dig, yet no one describes where to dig - there is still hope. The work itself, the experience it presents us becomes our hope and our choice, breaking the seemingly omnipotent paradox.

It would take 15 minutes or so for you to experience all this short little display can present you, and excluding its additional content - it is free. If you enjoy the experience though, I strongly recommend purchasing additional content, even to only support the developer. It is simplicity done right with a great atmosphere and fitting narrative. It is a bold little experience, created by an educated mind. I think we need more of its examples here around. Its sole existence, being wholly symbolic, provokes you to think. Please enjoy!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

34442520.review:
From Myshkin Entertainment comes Sisyphus Reborn, a simple point and click adventure game. 

Sisyphus Reborn is a short game that is heavy on atmosphere, but relatively light on puzzles; this game explores philosophical ideas in a short form. Waking up in a world where everyone merely digs forever, and no one dies, how do you find meaning in a meaningless world?

It took me a long time to figure out how to review this game. It gave me a lot to think about, and it made me question a lot of things in my life. For such a short game, it really left me stunned when the credits rolled. At first, I really didn’t think it could ever have such a massive effect on my life, but it really left me floored.

This is incredibly simple, first and foremost. The artwork isn’t amazing, but the audio tracks are absolutely stunning, and really help create the atmosphere around you as you play through the game. With a few light puzzles that aren’t that hard to crack (and there’s a walk through, if they do seem to be too hard), this is a pretty easy to complete game.

Enjoyable and short, with some achievements that are easy to collect, Sisyphus Reborn is a game I would personally say everyone should play and experience. Never before have I been so moved by a game, let alone a game that took under an hour to complete. This is a work of art, and I believe it should definitely be appreciated a lot more.

33816900.review:
At its most fundamental level, a game is only a series of questions that the player must answer with an action. Sisyphus Reborn manages to use this core nature to walk players through a complicated thought process. This may sound like a description of edutainment titles in general, but where this game succeeds and so many others fail is in its subtly. I wasn't aware I was learning until I read about Camus' Myth of Sisyphus in the discussion boards after playing. What motivated me to continue wasn't the need to complete an assignment but the need to discover more about the world constructed around his essay.

The landscapes themselves are left uncluttered, almost blank. Instead of flashy colors or movements, Sisyphus Reborn maintains visual interest with small tricks like distorting lines to mimic heat's effect on the horizon and stick figures that skip animated legs for wraith-like tails. Along with a soundtrack that focuses on note repetition and hints of religious music, the aesthetic builds a climate of sullen dread, one that implies you might be trapped in a sort of purgatory. It was that sense of disquiet that brought me back to learn more in a second playthrough.

The only complaint I'll level against Sisyphus Reborn is that your choices are laid out a little too neatly, as games are wont to do. There does seem to be a single correct choice in the end. All other alternatives are beset by hints towards that 'correct answer' and prompts to quit. But the player is free to ignore the developer's – and the philosopher's – answer in favor of their own and isn't that what philosophy is all about?

33608280.review:
Titled as the manuscript made by Albert Camus, father of the Absurd movement, this adventure game neatly deals with concepts of an individual having no purpose or meaning in the realm devoid of God or any other construct of Order, and how one might find happiness in only one way: accept the meaningless of life and enjoy in its mundanity, all thru endless work.

You are Sisyphus, man who has lived for unknown period of lives in a cave alone, and now you are scratching and fighting to reach the outside world so that you could make a decision: is life worth living or not? Made in AGS engine, graphics are simplistic 2D fare, but it is the artistic touch of the game's creator that give it an ethereal and mesmerizing quality, and the same goes for music. 

You'll need a very short time to reach through all Sisyphus Reborn endings, but in return it will leave you pondering on the meaning of life. A noble success, I'd say.

Unbelievable little game. Shocked my entire world for the 20 minutes I played it. It's an allegory, beautifully served and also a very enjoyable experience regardless. Recommended for anyone with a functional brain.

Here's my interpretation of the allegory.
[spoiler]We are born, without any idea what/who/why/where we are. We see the limited, but yet limitless world. It is filled with simpletons who do not understand anything else except "work to live, and that's all".
After some seeking, we find the shelter of the more intelligent person. They are willingly separated from the rest, but still have no clue as to why the world works that way. They (and thus, we) are bound as well by the rule "work to live or die doing nothing", but at least we understand that. 
We choose to live our own life, regardless of the result. [/spoiler]

33118964.review:
Summary: A short game about what it means to make choices in life and whether those choices are truly your own. And even if they are completely yours - do they truly mean anything? What's more worthy: to be complacent and achieve nothing yet lose nothing, surrounded by likeminded people; or live a much harder life by yourself, to one day break out of a stagnant, colorless world into regrowth and beauty? Is there truly only working, being nothing, and being alone? Are these choices made before we're ever aware of them, and if they are, does it matter? Does [i] anything [/i] matter?

Now to the the game itself: the art is what you see in the images, and the soundtrack is good. The writing is impactful, but short and direct. The controls are very simple but work for what's needed. I personally didn't have that life changing moment that some people did, but I did enjoy playing through it in half an hour, and I could see playing through it again every once in a while as a reminder to myself.

Overall - if you like short games that have a different pace and make you think a little bit, I fully recommend this game. And heck, it's free. If you easily spiral into exisistential crises (and don't enjoy it), don't play this. Otherwise? Check it out!

Wow. This 25-minute indie game is entirely a metaphor for finding your place in life. You start off within yourself and have to break out into the arid, outside world to find meaning to your existence. A majority of the people you meet along the way cannot help you, content to have their meaning defined by digging holes and filling them in again for eternity. Then you meet someone like you, a mentor who shows you the reality of the world: you can either work as a digger living a meaningless existence, or give up entirely and become nothing.

Finding your place in life isn't always easy, but every moment leading up to that self-discovery will have been worth it once you do.

(Sisyphus was a king condemned to roll a boulder up and down a hill for eternity)

30970649.review:
[h1] Eine philosophische Kurzgeschichte! [/h1]

Sisyphus Reborn ist ein kurzes 2D Point&Click Adventure, welches einfach super gestaltet wurde. Die Rätsel sind sehr einfach und das Hauptmerkmal liegt eindeutig auf der Geschichte. 

[b]Story[/b]
Wir wachen in einer kleinen Höhle auf und finden uns kurz darauf in der Wüste wieder. Wir wissen nicht wieso, aber unsere Möglichkeiten sind sehr begrenzt und entweder wir entscheiden uns, unser Leben sinnlos zu verbringen oder einfach aufzugeben. Aber Gott sei Dank haben wir als Spieler unser Schicksal selber in der Hand, sodass es auch zu einem guten Ende kommen kann. (Es gibt 4 Enden insgesamt.) 
Sisyphus ist dabei sehr philosophisch (Den Namen hat ja schon wer anders hier super erklärt) und Mottos die mir nach dem Spielen eingefallen sind, sind Dinge wie "Nicht aufgeben!" oder auch "Jeder ist seines eigenen Glückes Schmied".

[b]Grafik/Sound[/b]
Das Spiel wirkt so, als ob nur jemand der etwas besser als ich zeichnen kann das Spiel gemacht hat. Allerdings finde ich , und wohl auch der Autor, diesen Grafikstil als sehr angemessen, da sich das Spiel aufs Wesentliche konzentriert. Zudem wirkt das gute Ende so nochmal wesentlich optimistischer *zwinker*.
Die Musik ist einfach Top. Tiefgehendes Klavierspiel mit leichten Einsatz von Schlaginstrumenten, was von mir als sehr beruhigend und nicht störend empfunden wurde.

[b]Fazit[/b]
Sisyphus Reborn bietet eine wirklich schöne Kurzgeschichte, hinter der sich eine noch viel schönere Philosophie bzw. Lebenseinstellung versteckt. Das Spiel ist recht kurz, dafür aber gut und kostenlos. Meiner Meinung nach eines der besseren tiefgehenden Spiele, die ich mal gespielt habe. Ich werde es auf jeden Fall auch meinen Freunden ans Herz legen!

Wenn du dir das Spiel lieber anschauen willst, habe ich auf meinem Youtube Kanal einen gesamten Durchlauf des Spieles hochgeladen. Ich zeige das beste Ende und erkläre auch noch ein wenig über den Hintergrund und die Namensgebung des Spiels: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KTOL_vmJfIc
Ich freue mich immer über Kommentare oder Feedback.

踏入无尽的未知（沙漠），最终陷入疯狂；
放弃思考，失去一切（什么也不做）；
盲目地服从，从永恒的重复中寻获存在的意义（挖掘）；
追寻自己的道路，得以重生（进入新世界）

《西西弗斯的重生》，很有哲学意味的游戏。

[quote]根据《荷马史诗》，西西弗斯是人间最足智多谋的人，他是科林斯的建城者和国王。当宙斯掳走河神伊索普斯(Aesopus)的女儿伊琴娜(Aegina)，河神曾到科林斯找寻其女，知悉此事的西西弗斯以一条四季常流的河川做为交换条件告知。由于泄露了宙斯的秘密，宙斯便派出死神要将他押下地狱。没有想到西西弗斯却用计绑架了死神，导致人间长久以来都没有人死去，一直到死神被救出为止，西西弗斯也被打入冥界。

在被打入冥界前，西西弗斯嘱咐妻子墨洛珀(Merope)不要埋葬他的尸体。到了冥界后，西西弗斯告诉冥后帕尔塞福涅(Persephone)，一个没有被埋葬的人是没有资格待在冥界的，并请求给予三天告假还阳处理自己的后事。没有想到，西西弗斯一看到美丽的大地就赖着不走不想回冥府去了。直到其死后，西西弗斯被判逐出到地狱那边。

西西弗斯触犯了众神，诸神为了惩罚西西弗斯，便要求他把一块巨石推上山顶，而由于那巨石太重了，每每未上山顶就又滚下山去，前功尽弃，于是他就不断重复、永无止境地做这件事——诸神认为再也没有比进行这种无效无望的劳动更为严厉的惩罚了。西西弗斯的生命就在这样一件无效又无望的劳作当中慢慢消耗殆尽。

他的唯一的选择就是那块石头与那座陡山。[/quote]

[table][tr][td][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MentorPixel]Mentor Píxel[/url] - [i]El medio interactivo como entretenimiento inteligente[/i][/td][/tr][/table]

[i]Sisyphus Reborn[/i] sumerge al jugador en un mundo carente de sentido, lo que lleva a sus desesperados habitantes atrapados allí por toda la eternidad, a inventarse un propósito artificial por miedo a perder la propia identidad. Situados en un desierto infinito, ellos por siempre cavan grandes hoyos en la arena… con el único fin de volver a llenarlos.

[h1]Sísifo y Camus[/h1]
[i]“Cuenta el mito, que un día Sísifo divisó como Zeus secuestraba a una mujer. Al delatar al Dios del trueno, este mandó a su hermano Hades a que se llevase al mortal al mundo de los muertos. El mortal engaño a su perseguidor haciendo uso de su gran intelecto, y continuó engañando a todo aquél que intentara llevárselo. Finalmente, Hermes  lo acabó trasladando a rastras al más allá, en donde se le condenó a Sísifo a subir una roca a lo alto de una montaña de inconmensurable altura. Llegado a un punto, el ascenso se volvía vertical, y la roca caía de manera irremediable, por lo que el hombre debía volver a subirla, y así, por toda la eternidad, dando paso a un trabajo inútil y sin esperanza”.[/i]

[i]Sisyphus Reborn[/i] se basa en el aclamado libro de Albert Camus, “El mito de Sísifo”. Este filósofo, en su ensayo publicado en 1942, usa a Sísifo como metáfora para tratar el valor de la vida según lo que se haga con ella, lo que le lleva a deliberarse sobre la validez del suicidio ante una existencia que pierde su sentido. Camus veía a Sísifo como una parodia de la vida moderna; la tarea de subir aquella roca en representación del obrero que trabaja durante toda su vida, y la caída de la roca como un momento de libertad, liberación del obrero en su receso de trabajo antes de volver a empezar otra vez. Dicha comparación dio paso a una nueva filosofía.

[h1]Filosofía del absurdo[/h1]
El absurdismo –no confundir con nihilismo –, mejor conocido como filosofía del absurdo, nació con la obra de Camus anteriormente mencionada. La misma establece el absurdo de la búsqueda del ser humano en pos de hallar un significado a su propia existencia, y como esto, irremediablemente conlleva al fracaso debido a la inexistencia de dicho significado. Según el mismo escritor, la vida es insignificante y no posee más propósito que aquél impuesto por cada uno; aun así, el humano continuará haciendo uso de su conocimiento para buscar respuestas, incluso aunque deba inventarlas y transmitirlas a sus congéneres.

Sísifo es feliz, dice Camus. ¿Por qué? Su condena es eterna y su castigo despiadado, su vida fue despojada de todo fin, ¿qué le puede generar sensación de júbilo? Pues este hombre, continúa Camus, tiene ahora un propósito, un fin que a pesar de no poder verlo debido a la magnitud de la tragedia en la que se encuentra, podrá ver claramente en sus momentos de lucidez. Sísifo empuja cual hombre absurdo, rendido ante la voluntad de dioses, quienes han concedido su capricho de escapar a la muerte, otorgándole una vida eterna y un designio a cumplir. Pero al momento de caer su carga al punto de partida, el hombre es liberado de la tarea, y aunque sea solo un instante, experimenta dicha. Siendo feliz mientras no esté empujando la roca, puede crear un significado artificial a su castigo: pues él empuja la roca para ser dichoso cuando no la empuje, y eso le permite continuar subiéndola, ya que esa roca es lo que le da sentido a su existencia. Sísifo acaba cayendo en el absurdo, aceptando que la vida es un conjunto de repeticiones carentes de sentido que se llevan a cabo más por una cuestión de costumbre tradición o inercia que por coherencia y lógica.

[i]Sisyphus Reborn[/i] retrata todo aquello presentando un mundo cuyos habitantes cayeron en el absurdo, todos acaban siendo como Sísifo, cargando su propia roca personal. Ellos, pala en mano, por siempre cavan grandes hoyos en la arena… con el fin de llenarlos. Todos se crean el mismo designio artificial que justifique y valide su existencia por miedo a perder su sentido de la vida. 

Queda en manos del jugador, ser quien guíe al protagonista en pos de hallar finalmente un propósito verdadero, o rendirse y cavar por toda la eternidad. [spoiler]La pirámide situada en mitad del desierto participará en representación del absurdo, en dejarse encadenar a él y no hallar, sino crear, aquella felicidad que Sísifo experimentaba; algo artificial con la que uno justifica su propio absurdo. Y aquél desierto actúa como metáfora de la vida misma, imposibilitando el escape hacia otro lugar, pues más allá de donde alcanza la vista, solo hay más arena. Será entonces que se presentan al jugador dos opciones: vivir en acciones vanas o suicidarse (acción que es retratada mediante la inacción eterna, resultando en una existencia en estado vegetativo hasta el punto de no retorno). Una tercera opción, sin embargo, se encarga de exponer como una persona puede darle sentido a sus acciones, en lugar de que estas le den sentido a ella.[/spoiler]

29299821.review:
Sisyphus Reborn is a philosophical experience unlike any other

Story:

The plot of this game is finding a meaning in life in a meaningless world (as the description says). And it succeeds in doing so. There are multiple endings to the game as well.

Gameplay:

The gameplay is like a really simple point-and-click game. You do everything in the game with the mouse. It's not complex, but there are parts of the game that needs 'thinking' to be solved.

Graphics:

The graphic style fits. It's a simple handdrawn style, all done in black and white.

All in all, Sisyphus Reborn is a short, philosophical and somewhat emotional journey unlike anything you will ever see, and it's FREE! I would give this game a solid 9/10 atleast. Because it really deserves it.

- Denolact

I believe I'm a less common player on Steam, I buy games for several different reasons, some I buy for myself and also for other people, some games I prefer to watch and comment on instead of play. I collect games for their beauty, for their art design, for their challenge or if they convince me they have a good story. This "game" is, above all, a philosophical reading, you basically need to follow the only way of doing the things.

Inspired by the Albert Camus' essay in which he introduces his philosophy of the absurd: that of the man in search of meaning, unity and clarity in the face of an unintelligible world devoid of God and eternity. Does the realization of the absurd demand suicide? Camus replies: "No. It demands revolt." He then describes various approaches to the absurd in life. The last chapter compares the absurdity of man's life with the situation of Sisyphus, a personage of Greek mythology, condemned to always repeat the same task of pushing a rock to the top of a mountain, and every time he was almost at the top, the stone rolled down the mountain again to the point of departure by an irresistible force, completely invalidating the hard effort expended. You can and, sometimes, you have to do your own way, and even your closer beloved ones will be against you, because people are doctrinated to live an absurd life with no purpose other than gather properties. I call it contemporary (and cheap) slavery, the utilitarian and materialist world we live to serve purposes and reach goals that are not the ours.

I recommend the game for people who, like me, are not always in search of a game that fits the most common patterns (or that have the main) purpose of entertaining, Sisyphus Reborn is a good opportunity to reflect and entertain yourself with the very consciousness.

Nice music, very atmostpheric. The story is strange and deep, which each person can have their own view on it.

In the game, I found 4 choices: [spoiler]lost in wandering, become non-existence like some, dig mindlessly like others, or pave your own path[/spoiler]. Each person will lean toward one choice over others, or probably has their own ideas.

In my opinion, which you may agree or disagree, the story takes on the perspective of eternity to review what we do in daily life, individually and as a whole. Seeing how all actions become meaningless in the immortal life, does it worth to continue an action? We rush our life doing things we deem "significant", chasing "goals and objectives", and giving things "meaning" because our life is short. Many often yearn toward long life or immortality. But does it worth anything? After all, everything probably turns to dust in the end, including our planet, it's just beyond our current lifetime.

Anyway, it's a great thought-provoking adventure that you should give a try if you're into this genre.

所以西西弗斯的重生意味着啥呢？

'There is only one truly serious philosophical problem, and that is whether or not to make point-and-click games about digging.' 
-Albert Camus, absurdist philosopher, rock enthusiast and amateur video game developer

Finally, after more than a 40 year hiatus, Albert Camus Simulator 2016 has been released. Join our angsty minimalist protagonist as he goes on an epic quest to prove nihilists once and for all that they can go suck a fat one. 
Featuring rocks, holes we dig in order to fill the holes in our existence and REVOLT, Sisyphus Reborn is sure to be a thrill for absurdists of all ages!
Warning. Myshkin Entertainment and Valve Software hold no responsibility whatsoever for any existential crises caused by playing this game. Revolt against meaninglessness responsibly.

In all seriousness, though, this game's pretty neat. Sure, its gameplay is simplistic, but hey, it manages to convey, along with the hauntingly atmospheric music and visuals, the author's message succesfully, so that's a big plus for me. I hope we'll get to see more games by this studio, Steam could use some actually interesting philsophical games instead of the usual pseudo-intellectual rubbish. You keep pushing that rock up that mountain, Myshkin Entertainment, you hear?

26079152.review:
This is a very short, but also very intense and interesting game. The gameplay, based on point-and-click adventures, is minimal, but the same cannot be said about the content which is actually a deep and even disturbing reflection on human life itself. As such, this game quickly develops into a thought-provoking philosophical experience, loosely based on the classical myth about Sisyphus (who was ordered by the gods to push a stone uphill over and over and over, since it always rolled back at a certain point) with some extra thoughts by Albert Camus thrown in.

Usually, I'd skip through a game as crudely drawn as this one, with only the most basic of artwork. But the texts and the interactions - even though they mostly seemed meaningless to the absurd - quickly grabbed my attention, and I played through it at a leisurely pace. Though the game is very short (I played through it in half an hour, reading everything), it shouldn't have been any longer given its thought-provoking nature. The almost minimalistic sound track does provide the right amount of extra atmosphere at the right moments.

All in all: well done, and certainly worth trying out if you're into games that dig (excuse me the pun) deeper than most. You get a very easy 100% achievement game as a bonus, but that feels completely trivial after playing a game with this kind of content.

25766477.review:
According to Greek mythology, Sisyphus was the king of Ephyra. As a punishment for his deceitful ways, in the afterlife he was forced to hoist a massive boulder up a hill, only to watch it come back down; Sisyphus was damned to repeat these actions for all eternity. Sisyphus Reborn takes on a similar concept, although instead of a boulder the punishment is digging holes and refilling them for eternity.

There are multiple ways that this game can be interpreted. The first, and most obvious, being that the little ghostly fellow that you play as is dead, and is condemned to an afterlife of monotony. The second, which was my interpretation, is that the game is about life, and how a lot of nihilistic people see it; mostly meaningless and devoid of any sort of grand purpose. Why are you digging? To live. Why do you live? To dig. Digging is work, and we must work to live, and we live to work, giving most of our adult life is spent at our jobs.

Despite whatever that you may take away from Sisyphus Reborn, the title is excellent for a free game; despite its very simple nature. There are a few puzzles, all relatively simple. All of the graphics are hand drawn, and appear to be scanned instead of done in Photoshop or any other sort of digital art program. The music is very ambient, and it lends to a ghostly, eerie sort of atmosphere which is very appropriate. The dialogue is thought provoking, and to get the full effect of the game you will really need to do a couple of playthroughs as there are a couple different options to choose from.

The greatest thing about Sisyphus Reborn, aside from its price, is the opportunity to interpret the game as you wish. It's a very abstract piece, and what I saw in it you may not necessarily see, and what you see in it your friend may see something totally different. It's wonderful how a game so simple can have a different meaning to multiple individuals. Know, however, that there are no in-game settings or save system. However, the game does only take between 15-20 minutes to complete.

25716182.review:
Сизиф прогневал богов и за это был приговорен тащить в гору огромный булыжник. Но боги и сами могли затащить каменюку на гору.  Задача была в том, чтобы заставить Сизифа страдать. Поэтому камень постоянно скатывался, и ему приходилось начинать все сначала. Таким образом, выражение «Сизифов труд» означает тяжелую, но бесполезную деятельность. Эта игра не про Древнюю Грецию. Но все же в ней вам дадут ощутить  атмосферу безнадежности и бессмысленности действий. 
Судя по титрам, игра иностранная. Хотя название разработчика Myshkin Entertainment  вызывает мысли о том, что он отечественный. 
Хочется отметить, что среди бесплатных игр без доната, т.е. игр, рассказывающих какую-то небольшую историю, Sysyphus Reborn [b]хотя бы похожа [/b] на игру. Там можно немного побродить, немного взаимодействовать с предметами. Также есть диалоги, мини-квесты, возможность выбора и даже разные концовки. Поистине «личинка» игры. Был бы масштаб да технические возможности побольше, а графика – не простенькие каракули, а трехмерные модели со множеством полигонов, - и это был бы прямо Fallout-4! А так, простенькая, грустная философская зарисовка. 
Вначале герой оказывается в пещере. Лишь вдали, ему кажется, он видит слабый свет. Неужели это аллегория на пещеру древнегреческого философа Платона, иллюстрирующая, что люди воспринимают реальность по-разному?! Но нет, Платон не писал про сталагмиты и про то, чтобы пробить себе дорогу случайно подвернувшимся камнем. Когда же герой кое-как выбрался, словно Бакара Урднот после обряда посвящения,  он увидел такую неприглядную картину, что хоть в пещеру обратно возвращайся. Получив от местных жителей «очень интересные» и «объясняющие все» ответы на вопросы (кто я? Ты – это ты. Где я? Ты здесь), герой открывает четыре варианта концовки: [spoiler] копать всю жизнь; уйти; не предпринимать ничего и стать в итоге одним из тех существ в толпе, которых в игре называют страшным словом brain-dead.  И последний вариант – найти свой собственный путь. Хотя он и выглядит со стороны как-то нелепо. Самокопание какое-то в буквальном смысле. [/spoiler] Интересно, что за одно прохождение можно перепробовать все варианты, просто выбирать «Нет», когда при достижении одного финала появляется меню с предложением выйти из игры.  Но дело в том, что какую бы концовку вы ни выбрали, это нисколько не приближает к разгадке – что происходит в этом странном месте и почему герой там оказался. Таким образом, все усилия героя напрасны. Вот он Сизифов труд. Истина непостижима.  Разве только в одной концовке, той, что в пещере, есть какой-то оптимизм. Ее можно понимать как намек: сначала разберись в самом себе, а потом познавай мир. При выборе этого варианта можно наблюдать в игре какой-то очередной непостижимый и непонятный процесс, но с подписью «возрождение».
Не понимаю, почему в эти простенькие бесплатные игры часто пытаются закладывать «высокие философские» идеи? Ведь технические возможности таких игр практически не позволяют как следует оценить и проникнуться этими высокими измышлениями. Зачастую даже складывается впечатление, что это просто надумано - попытка пустить пыль в глаза, тогда как никакого особенно высокого смысла там и нет. И разве на такие игры обратят внимание студенты философских отделений или ученые? Я имею в виду, не лучше ли создавать веселое приключение типа «прыгай через водопроводные трубы, собирай монетки, добеги до пирамидки и опусти флаг»? Ой, нет, так получится легендарная известная игра. 
Как бы то ни было, несмотря на то, что Sysyphus Reborn  -  игра немного печальная,  она способна понравиться игроку и оставить в целом положительные впечатления.

25681699.review:
This game is a good game.
This is a good game because it does its job as a game; it speaks to the player, the observer, in the artistic manner that is exclusive to games as a medium. The same experience could not have been had via a movie, book, or oral storytelling.
[i] Sisyphus Reborn [/i] communicates not only the uniquely-human philosophical conundrum of purpose (in the form of the question "Why do anything?"), but does so in a way that makes the player ask the question themselves. In a movie, images and sounds are simply absorbed by the viewer, and in many cases that is the most effective way of moving them artistically. As a game, however, [i] Sisyphus Reborn [/i] moves the player via interaction, by making them decide for themselves, by their own reasoning, their acceptance or rejection of one philosophical stance or another. By the end of it, the player has been tricked into thinking, which is exactly what good art (and good games) ought to do.

The game is free (as some believe art ought to be). You've got nothing to lose but less than an hour which would likely have been wasted elsewhere. Give it a shot. Tell others to do the same. You might just learn something about yourself.

25606162.review:
"Sisyphus Reborn" ist eine kleine kostenlose Allegorie, ein kurzes atmosphärisches Exploration-Game, das zum Nachdenken anregt.

Wir wachen als eine Art Strichmännchen auf in einer unbekannten Höhle, ohne zu wissen, wer wir sind, wo wir sind oder welches Ziel wir haben. Mehr zu erzählen würde den Prozess des Nachdenkens im Spiel reduzieren, also: einfach selber zocken.

Nur soviel: Der Autor weiß genau was er tut. Er kombiniert hochintelligent den klassischen Mythos des Sisyphos - der König von Korinth, der zur Strafe für seine Verschlagenheit oder vielleicht auch nur für seine Intelligenz einen Felsen ewig auf einen Berg schaffen mußte und dieser Felsen rollte stets wieder zurück ins Tal - mit Albert Camus "Mythos des Sisyphos", in dem Camus die Absurdität der menschlichen Existenz beschreibt, die aus der Spannung zwischen der Sinnlosigkeit der Welt und der Sehnsucht des Menschen nach Sinnhaftigkeit erwächst (zur Lektüre empfohlen). Dazu mischt er neben anderen Philosophen auch noch ein wenig platonisches Höhlengleichnis und braut daraus eine inspirierende kleine Parabel, eine Allegorie auf das Leben und die Fragen nach Schicksal und Vorbestimmung, Freiheit und Sinn. Und das Ergebnis fungiert als das, was Kunst im besten Falle sein soll: als Katalysator für das eigene Hirn.

Passende grafische Reduktion und ein gelungener kleiner Soundtrack runden den qualitativ hochwertigen Eindruck ab.

Eine kleine, glänzende Perle. 

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
10/10 Atmosphäre
10/10 Story
9/10 Grafik
9/10 Sound
5/10 Spielmechanik
10/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Gibt es einen Sinn im Leben? Ich weiß es nicht. Ich weiß nur, daß es viel Sinn macht, "Sisyphus Reborn" zu erleben.

[h1][b]10/10 Gesamtwertung

[h1]Fortune cookie philosophy that takes up to half an hour to read and isn't edible[/h1]

I'm a little torn with Sisyphus. 
On one hand I think it is highly pretentious and with barely any content.
On the other it is completely free, does not take too much time to do everything, and does carry a deeper message on finding meaning in a meaningless existence.

[h1] It's not as good as it thinks it is but is still worth playing[/h1]

With very a minimalist art style your character wakes up in a cave with no memory and must navigate a barren landscape where death is not an escape and the only meaning to existence is to dig or not to dig.
The game howver will take at least 15 minutes to explain that particular part to you. 

The game controls identically to a point and click adventure complete with a couple of "use items on..." puzzles so game navigation feels instantly familiar and natural though those unused to such throwback titles will be pleased to know there is a simple tutorial on the controls that does not get in the way of the immersion to much.

So while I left the game experience feeling fairly unsatisfied I do believe the game has something to offer at no cost and presents it to you in a reasonable time. I reccomend you give this unique little title a try if only to make up your own mind.

25502111.review:
[h1]Sisyphus Reborn: Metaphorical masterpiece or pretentious pile of crap?[/h1]

Anyone with a brain (and access to the Steam Store) can plainly see the sheer volume of free, independently developed games available to play. Wade through the chest high sea of titles and major trends start to pop out: bad copies of iOS games, badly executed "free"-to-play games, and the ever present "art" game. With many reviewers adamant that "this game isn't even a game" and "lol French new wave level of pointlessly esoteric dialogue", one is tempted to relegate Sisyphus Reborn as one of the other walking simulators touted as "art" games. That assumption is false. Sisyphus Reborn is an actual art game because it does what vast majority of similar titles fail to do: it makes you think. While a bit on-the-nose at times, make no mistake, Sisyphus Reborn is the most well thought out interactive interpretations of existentialist philosophy there is. Through a barely twenty minute campaign, the game enables the player to experience Albert Camus' concept of the modern Sisyphus, a human who recognizes life's innate meaninglessness, and forges their own path based on their choices in spite of it. I especially reccomend this game due to the way it drastically lowers the barrier to entry of existentialist philosophy. It simplifies Camus' extensive meditations regarding suicide and the true meaning of life (or lack thereof). In the future, I'd like to see this game developer's interpretation of other philosophers (Schopenhauer's perspective on sex, perhaps?).

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

Game is good. Makes people think.

Sisyphus has to roll the boulder up the hill every day. This task is meaningless by itself. Sisyphus is not performing this task because something better awaits him once it's done. This is all there is. It is absurd. Sisyphus can embrace the absurdity of the task and choose to be happy in spite of (or even, because of!) it.

Similarly, life is inherently absurd. There is no meaning. We can either rail against the infinite injustice of this, or we can whistle and continue to push that boulder up that hill. Instead of looking for the ultimate meaning of things and being disappointed with what we find, we can, quite simply, choose to be happy. This a conscious choice that we have to make. Once we embrace the absurd, we can focus on the actions that will bring joy to us and others around us during our short time on our home planet.  - Vandita Kapoor

To dig or not to dig. That is the question.

Hey everyone! This is jrince and here is my review of Sisphyus Reborn!!

I first want to preface saying that if you want to see gameplay than check out my full playthrough over on youtube: https://youtu.be/9a0KTB3-mDo

Sisyphus Reborn is a thought provoking experience, because that is what this is it is an experience more than a game. The gameplay is a very simple point and click adventure with simplified puzzles, but those are just the catalyst for a fantastic story. This game would be a more simplified version of say abzu or Journey if i was to make a comparison. It is more about the adventure itself and the meaning of it than anything else.

The dialogue has its funny moments but once you stop and think about what the words mean than it almost reminds me of my Intro to Philosphy class because you can honestly dig deep in what is being said. 


Pros

Fantastic Story
Interesting hand drawn Art and Music
Multiple Endings ;-)
Thought Provoking (Hey this is great if a game achieves this!)
The Game is FREE there is no reason not to try it!

Cons

it is short
it is mostly reading
There is one puzzle that is definately frustrating!



Overall I TOTALLY recommend that even if you watch my gameplay to try the experience for yourself or even just download it to show the developer support... It is FREE after all the pros certainly outweigh the cons.

25417419.review:
Sisyphus Reborn es un videojuego donde el jugador interactúa en un mundo sin sentido, de personas con discursos sin sentidos y le han atribuído sentido a lo sin sentido. Como jugador, deberás buscar el sentido de vivir en un mundo sin sentido, donde lo absurdo resulta no absurdo para algunos pero para otros sí, como tú. Te reencarnarás en un personaje quien decidirá si las acciones de otros tienen sentido alguno o no, y donde le atribuirás un sentido a las unicas tres cosas que puedes hacer en este mundo: "Cavar", "Hacer nada"; "Crear un búcle con sentido sin-sentido".

Sisyphus Reborn te abre el paso a explorar un mundo lleno de filósofos, relatores de lo absurdo y la búsqueda del significado del objeto; de la persona y objeto como tal, y con ellos los sentidos o significancias que le atribuyes a los diversos sistemas, planos y eventos de tu vida y la del resto.

El título del videojuego (se infiere) proviene de una personaje de la mitología Griega... del cual contarte estaría arruinando parte de lo que trata el videojuego.

Échale un vistazo, a simple razón no encontrarás grandeza pero si te das el tiempo de leer un poco más y masticar lo que has jugado/interactuado, te darás cuenta un poco más el por qué escribo una reseña medianamente extensa al promedio.

9/10 - Un juego para pensar y concientizar.

Excuso mi falta de redacción y faltas ortográficas,
¡Suerte!

25393420.review:
ポイントクリックアドベンチャーゲーム。
ふと気づくと暗い洞窟にいた。洞窟の奥のかすかな光に希望を見出して外にでると一面の砂漠、そしてひたすら穴を掘っている人々がいた。ここはどこなのか？なぜ穴を掘っているのか？この砂漠から抜け出すには？…という展開から始まる物語。

オーソドックスなポイントクリックアドベンチャーで哲学的なテーマを持ったゲームだ。手書き風のアートワークも特徴の1つとなっている。タイトルにもある通りに「シーシュポスの岩」という話を下敷きにしている。その話は「人は皆いずれは死んで全ては水泡に帰す事を承知しているにも拘わらず、それでも生き続ける人間の姿」を描いたもので、このゲームでは無駄になるかもしれないことをやり続ける信念、葛藤と決断を描いている。

残念ながら日本語非対応で、文章が勝手に流れるタイプなので英語が苦手な人にとっては厳しいゲームだ。英語が苦手でも読む気があるなら、ウィンドウモードで起動して非アクティブにすればゲームは停止するので、その間に文章を読むといいだろう。
ボリュームは少なくクオリティも無料ゲーム相応といったところだが、話のテーマは良いので英語に抵抗がなければプレイすると良いと思う。

25391192.review:
Wow...I was not expecting this... It's dark, it's creepy, it's depressing, it IS a psychological horror...but it's worth it.  Without spoiling it, here is my review of [i]Sisyphus Reborn[/i].

In an unknown limbo-like world, you awaken.  Strange figures, stranger people with even stranger minds, and a single question...to dig or to not dig?  The choice is yours...or are there other choices with other consequences?

The music is beautifully composed by Edwin Montomgery, who crafts music that fits the eerie mood within this short work (which should take you about 30 minutes, give or take a few).  The most beautiful and captivating is the main theme, simply labeled [i]Sisyphus Reborn[/i]...haunting, yet beautiful.

The art-style to this game is very simplistic, though it feels amateurly done...but to fit the eerie mood of this title, it works.  It's supposed to feel wrong, because the world is wrong...or is it right?

This whole game is a short experience that makes you think.  In the end, you realize how much a choice that belongs to you truly matters.  It's free, it's short, it has achievements.  You can't go wrong here.  My only complaints are that the text auto-scrolls a little too quickly for me and the text can be hard to read (White on white.  Dark grey on grey/black...)

8/10 I chose to dig.  It was my choice.

25386016.review:
Sisyphus Reborn è un breve punta e clicka ideato dall'australiano Edwin Montgomery, principalmente musicista impegnato in soundtrack per film e videogiochi (sue ad es. alcune tracce di Warhammer:4000, Homefront: The Revolution, Wasteland). Vedo che molte recensioni su questa pagina consigliano di affrontare l'esperienza con occhi "vergini" e senza preconcetti, ma mi consento di dissentire. SR è un titolo fortemente intellettualistico, di cui si riesce a cogliere la vera natura soltanto avendo perlomeno un'idea vaga della sua fonte ispiratrice, peraltro rivelata nei titoli di coda. SR non è altro che una rappresentazione videoludica de Le mythe de Sisyphe. Essai sur l'absurde, opera di Camus del 1942, condita di simboli reinterpretati secondo la sensibilità dello sviluppatore ma comunque sia decisamente fedele al messaggio dell'originale: mi basterebbe rinviarvi alla pagina di Wikipedia dell'opera, che io stesso ho visitato, per avere una panoramica sufficiente al nostro compito di fruitori. Per non essere superfluo, mi limiterò qui a fare un minimo di gioco associativo tra quello che ho letto e quello che ho giocato. Sisifo è una figura mitologica della tradizione greca, scaltro trickster che in più occasioni si dimostrò capace di strumentalizzare le divinità con cui di volta in volta si trovò a che fare. La punizione di Zeus dopo un tentativo di fuga dal Tartaro fu quella di dover spingere un masso verso la cima di un declivio, senza tuttavia mai riuscirci, per il resto dell'eternità. Si capisce già che Sisifo, nel gioco, sono gli abitanti dello spoglio Tartaro tratteggiato a penna, impegnati nell'atelica attività di scavare e ricoprire le buche fatte. Cosa aggiunge Camus a questo quadro? Per l'autore Sisifo è la personificazione dell'"uomo assurdo", ovvero la condizione che ontologicamente ci connota come esseri viventi senza alcuna vera motivazione. Tuttavia, per Camus la figura di Sisifo non è quella di un uomo intrappolato in una punizione eterna, ma quella di un essere "da immaginare come felice", in quanto pienamente consapevole dei suoi limiti concreti, libero dunque dalle preoccupazioni per le cause dell'essere e per il futuro, esempio di "sopportazione" dell'esistenza. Qual è l'alternativa di Camus a questo modello? Una è quella che lo rinnega completamente: è la figura del suicida, sulla quale si dovrebbe concentrare tutta la scienza filosofica. Il suicidio è lo stato indotto dall'indagine del vuoto esistenziale, e concretizzato dallo spezzarsi delle azioni quotidiane, fino a una soffocazione delle stesse capacità di interazione: sono le figure raggruppate apaticamente in vari punti del deserto. L'altra è quella prediletta dall'autore. Non so quanto sia proprio definire quest'ultima un'alternativa: Montgomery stesso lascia la rappresentazione nell'ambiguità inducendo il giocatore al tentativo di fuga tramite lo stesso mezzo usato dai "Sisifi" per sopravvivere, ovvero lo scavo. Probabilmente "variante" è un concetto giusto. Camus sceglie di "bruciare" la sua esistenza, in una cosciente rivolta verso la falsa libertà, con il fuoco dell'assenza di obiettivi, del disinteresse, che si rivelano inaspettatamente l'altra faccia della medaglia della passione e del bene trovato nel Tutto. Camus è il giocatore: la via personale di accettazione dell'esistenza è sì solitaria, ma va alle radici della vita (l'acqua che si insinua nei meandri della terra) e conduce infine non tanto a una fuga, ma a una rinascita in un mondo sensoriale, colorato, "pieno", in una prospettiva ciclica angosciosa e ottimistica al tempo stesso. Figure non molto chiare (magari soltanto nella mia ignoranza) sono quella dell' "Esegeta" dentro la piramide e del tentativo di fuga tramite esplorazione "superficiale" del deserto. La prima potrebbe essere Montgomery stesso. Si manifesta come compositore e conoscitore del mondo che presenta al protagonista, e il suo aprire le porte al suo regno soltanto dopo la dimostrazione di una capacità di imitazione potrebbe voler simboleggiare un tentativo di trovare un'affinità con coloro ai quali è destinato questo prodotto. Per la seconda, potrebbe essere banalmente un riferimento alla futilità di cercare un punto di riferimento rimanendo al livello "apparente" della questione, che risulta così disarmante e vasta da indurre la perdita di sanità mentale. 
In SR c'è molta ambizione, molta più di quanta un progetto dalla durata di mezz'ora possa probabilmente contenere. Una condensazione così ermetica di un saggio filosofico (anche se l'autore non vorrebbe definirlo così) risulta infatti facilmente oscura o banalizzata dall'assenza di conoscenze pregresse, ma forse fin troppo "didascalica" essendone in possesso. Gli elementi di reintrepretazione personale non riescono ad essere abbastanza incisivi da lasciare un'immagine chiara di Montgomery dietro quella di Camus: dello sviluppatore risalta però bene la sensibilità artistica, in un'unione veramente toccante di soluzioni grafiche e sonore. Un'operazione culturale degna di nota dunque, ma che non può non lasciare in bocca un retrogusto di "prototipo": sicuramente SR è un degno precedente di chiunque vorrà perseguire simili progetti in futuro.

25384579.review:
A very cerebral experience.  I came to it with an existing appreciation of Camus' work, so I enjoyed it.  The game certainly won't be for everyone though.

In terms of content, it's basically a reflection on Camus' myth condensed into a thirty-minute, very simplistic point-and-click adventure game.  There's no real gameplay to speak of, but that's not the point, I believe.  This is certainly one of those "games" that's more of an "interactive experience" than what people tend to consider a "proper" game.

If all of that is what you're looking for then you'll probably like this.  It's very well done for what it is.
